name: solanum-tuberosum
definition: The potato is a root vegetable native to the Americas, a starchy tuber of the plant Solanum tuberosum, and the plant itself, a perennial in the family Solanaceae.
description:
Potato is an herbaceous perennial plant grown for its edible tubers.

The potato plant has a branched stem and alternately arranged leaves consisting of leaflets which are both of unequal size and shape.

The leaflets can be oval to oblong in shape and the leaves can reach 10 to 30 centimeters in length and 5 to 15 centimeters wide.

The potato tubers grow underground and generally located in the top 25 centimeters of the soil.

The tubers can range in color from yellow to red or purple depending on the variety.

Potato plants can reach in excess of one meter in height and are grown as annual plants, surviving only one growing season.

Potato tubers are a staple food source in temperate regions and are eaten after cooking.

They may be cut or sliced and made into potato chips or fries.

Potatoes can also be processed into starch, alcohol or flour.

Potatoes are cool season crops which grow best in cooler climates or as a winter crop in areas with warm summers.

They are sensitive to heat but can tolerate a light frost.

Cultivation of potatoes is easier, faster and requires less fertilizers compared to the cultivation of other crops.

They will grow optimally at daytime temperatures between 18 and 27°C and night time temperatures between 12 and 18°C.

Plants can also be successfully grown outdoors in burlap bags or large containers.

Potatoes are usually grown from seed potatoes.

Small sections of a large tuber known as seed pieces can also be used.

Seed potatoes and pieces are planted 0 to 2 weeks after the last frost, in early spring.

Space the seed pieces 30 centimeters apart and cover with 7.5 cm of soil.

Potato originates from South America.

Over 99% of presently cultivated potatoes worldwide descended from varieties that originated in the lowlands of south-central Chile.

Potatoes were domesticated approximately 7,000–10,000 years ago.

Potatoes were introduced to Europe from the Americas in the second half of the 16th century by the Spanish.

facts.name: Rich source of starch
facts.value: Potatoes are rich source of carbohydrates (starch), vitamin C and vitamins of the B group. They also have high content of fibers and important minerals. Potatoes need to be cooked before consumption. Most popular dishes include mashed potato, French-fried potato, boiled and baked potato.

facts.name: Green parts of potato are toxic
facts.value: Green parts of potato contain substance called solanine. This substance induces toxic effects in humans. Main purpose of solanine is to protect plant from the predators.

facts.name: Blue potato is from South America
facts.value: Blue potato is a variety of potato that originates from South America. Skin and flesh of this potato are purple, but they become blue after cooking. Blue color comes from high concentration of pigment called anthocyanin.

facts.name: Staple food in numerous countries
facts.value: Potato is staple food in numerous countries around the world. Great Irish Famine in 19th century was a consequence of fungal disease of potato (known as potato blight). Fast spreading disease and lack of potatoes led to nearly million human deaths.

facts.name: Annual production
facts.value: Over 300 million tons of potatoes are produced each year. Greatest amount of potato is produced in China.

facts.name: White, red, purple or blue flowers
facts.value: Potato can produce white, red, purple or blue flowers. Color of the flower is closely associated with the color of the skin (plant with white flower has white skin). Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI used flowers of potato in decorative purposes.

facts.name: Size of potato depends on variety
facts.value: Size of potato plant depends on variety. It usually grows 60 centimeters in height. Largest ever recorded potato had 8.1 kilograms of weight (enough for preparing 73 portions of medium sized French fries).

facts.name: Potato was launched in space
facts.value: Potato is the first plant that was launched and successfully grown inside the space shuttle in 1995.

facts.name: Edible part is the underground stem
facts.value: Edible part of the potato is underground stem, better known as tuber.

facts.name: Usually pollinated by insects
facts.value: Potatoes are usually pollinated by insects such as bumblebees.

facts.name: Average annual consume
facts.value: On average, each person on the planet eats 33 kilograms of potato each year.

facts.name: Versatile reproduction methods
facts.value: Potato can reproduce via seeds, tubers and cuttings.

facts.name: Prone to viral diseases
facts.value: Potatoes are prone to viral, bacterial and fungal diseases. Also, they are often targeted by various insects and worms that lay eggs and eat various parts of potato.

facts.name: Genetically modified potatoes
facts.value: Scientists developed several genetically modified potatoes in the last couple of decades. New types of potatoes are resistant to pests, able to survive in various climates and/or enriched in proteins.

facts.name: Potato is a perennial plant
facts.value: Potato is perennial plant, which means that it can survive more than two years in the wild.
